Nitrogen doping carbon deriving from ionic liquid anchoring Ru coated on P-zeolite as high activity and stability catalyst for the catalytic wet air oxidation of highly concentrated ammonia Chaojie Gai a 1 Hongbing Song a 1 Xiaofeng Liu a Fukun Li b Meng Xiao a Tingting Huang a Hengjun Gai a ⁎ a College of Chemical Engineering, Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Zhengzhou Road NO. 53, Qingdao, China College of Chemical Engineering Qingdao University of Science and Technology Zhengzhou Road NO. 53 Qingdao China aCollege of Chemical Engineering, Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Zhengzhou Road NO. 53, Qingdao, China b Chongqing Key Laboratory of Catalysis and New Environmental Materials, College of Environment and Resources, Chongqing Technology and Business University, Chongqing, 400067, China Chongqing Key Laboratory of Catalysis and New Environmental Materials College of Environment and Resources Chongqing Technology and Business University Chongqing 400067 China bChongqing Key Laboratory of Catalysis and New Environmental Materials, College of Environment and Resources, Chongqing Technology and Business University, Chongqing, 400067, China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. The treatment of the highly concentrated ammonia–nitrogen wastewater major produced in the coal chemical industry is a challenging problem. Herein, a novel catalyst with high activity and hydrothermal stability was designed for the catalytic wet air oxidation (CWAO) of the highly concentrated ammonia. In the designed catalytic system, P-zeolite was treated with sodium hydroxide to form defects for enhancing the adsorption of active metals. And the ionic liquid was employed as an N-doped carbon coating on treated P-zeolite to protect the ruthenium nanoparticles from leaching and improve its hydrothermal stability. The simultaneous introduction of ionic liquid and Ru precursor was beneficial to the dispersion of Ru on P-zeolite. The resulting catalyst Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC overcomes the poor hydrothermal stability of zeolite and exhibits excellent catalytic performance during the CWAO of highly concentrated ammonia. The catalyst of 1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC offers 100% conversion under 2 MPa at 200 °C in 4 h for 2000 ppm ammonia. No substantial deactivation was observed after five cycles. This study provides an effective strategy for the application of N-doped carbon coating on zeolite in CWAO systems. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords N-doped carbon Ionic liquid Zeolite Catalytic wet air oxidation Highly concentrated ammonia 1 Introduction Ammonia containing wastewater is widely produced in coal and oil processing, steel and fertilizers manufacturing, food processing, landfill, and other human industrial production and life [1, 2]. As we all know, ammonia nitrogen will bring water eutrophication and atmospheric ammonium particles and other environmental problems [1–3]. Therefore, the treatment of ammonia–nitrogen wastewater must be paid attention to. The concentration of ammonia in wastewater varies significantly depending on the different sources. For high concentration ammonia containing wastewater with concentration of 2000–3000 ppm from industrial production process, steam stripping is generally adopted to recover most of ammonia [4–7]. After that, biological process composed of nitrification and denitrification is employed for further treatment [8–12]. Although the energy consumption of this route is very high, it has a definite economic significance because it can recover a lot of ammonia products. However, a large amount of wastewater such as landfill leachate has ammonia nitrogen content between 1000 and 2000 ppm, which is neither directly treated by the biological method, and it is not cost-effective to set up a steam stripping unit. Therefore, the treatment of ammonia-nitrogen wastewater with the concentration of 1000–2000 ppm with less investment and low operating cost has a good research prospect. As an emerging wastewater treatment technology, catalytic wet air oxidation (CWAO) technology can oxidize organic and ammonia–nitrogen pollutants into harmless substances such as CO2 and N2 under certain temperatures (150 °C–320 °C) and pressure (0.5–20 MPa) with the help of a catalyst [13–16]. Compared with other physical and chemical treatment methods (such as steam stripping [4–6], ion exchange [17, 18], adsorption [19], folding point chlorination [20, 21], and chemical precipitation [22–24] etc.), this technology neither requires a secondary treatment for ammonia-nitrogen nor introduces secondary pollution due to the avoidance of chemical agents. Hence, this strategy has competitive advantages in the economy and technology. A catalyst with good performance can lower the reaction temperature and speed up the reaction time. Therefore, the design and development of the catalyst has become the key to CWAO technology. There are a large number of studies on ammonia-containing wastewater CWAO [25–28]. For example, Qin et al. [29]. applied the impregnation method to load 3% precious metals Ru, Rh, Pd, or Pt and transition metals Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, or Ni on the Al2O3 carrier and studied the effect of different metal types on the activity of ammonia–nitrogen CWAO reaction. The results show that precious metals have better catalytic performance than non-precious metals. To reduce the amount of noble metals, Fu et al. [30]. developed an efficient and stable low Ru content catalyst based on the properties of Ru and Cu to coordinate oxygen species for the CWAO of ammonia. In our previous research, we developed several CWAO catalysts under different supports, and the application results showed satisfactory catalytic performance [31, 32]. The above and many other studies have achieved good research progress [33–35]. However, to develop industrial application processes, except catalyst performance, additional attention must be paid to factors such as catalyst cost and stability. Based on cost consideration, zeolite is cheap and available, undoubtedly has cost advantages [36]. In terms of catalytic performance, zeolite possesses abundant surface acid centers and stable framework structure. Many studies have confirmed that it has excellent catalytic effects [37–40]. However, the poor hydrothermal stability of zeolite restricts its application in industrial catalysis. This is because P-type zeolite has a low silicon-to-aluminum ratio, and hydrolysis in water will cause the framework to fall off, and even cause the molecular sieve structure to collapse. Therefore, finding ways to improve the hydrothermal stability of zeolite can increase the possibility of industrial application. Alkaline solution treatment and coating [41, 42] are effective strategies to enhance the stability of zeolite. These processes aim to protect metal particles from leaching [43] and improve the hydrothermal stability of the carrier. When zeolite is treated in an alkaline solution [44], the silicon on its framework can be removed [45–47]. Defects are consequently formed [48], which is conducive to the adsorption of active metals. Under hydrothermal conditions, carbon is stable because it is hydrophobic and therefore less susceptible to hydrolysis at high temperatures. Pham et al. [49]. used a hydrophobic carbon coating on the surface of mesoporous silica to convert the silica from hydrophilic to hydrophobic, thus improving the hydrothermal stability of supported catalysts Pd-carbon-silica in the aqueous phase hydrogenation reaction. The N-doped carbon can promote the dispersion and stability of the metal on the support through the electron transfer effect between N and the active metal, thus enhancing the catalytic activity and stability of the catalyst. Li et al. [50] employed a platinum-based catalyst to anchor Pt particles on N-doped carbon rods, which exhibited excellent stability in the liquid phase reaction system. Therefore, the N-doped [51] carbon coating of supported precious metal catalysts may enhance the catalytic performance and stability of ammonia–nitrogen wastewater. To date, the catalytic oxidation of ammonia–nitrogen on noble metal-coated catalysts has not been studied. This work aims to develop Ru nanoparticles supported on zeolite with high activity and hydrothermal stability for the CWAO of ammonia with high concentration. The designed catalyst was prepared through several processes such as hydrothermal synthesis, sodium hydroxide corrosion, simultaneous introduction of ionic liquid and Ru precursor, carbonization, and reduction. In the preparation process, the zeolite treated with sodium hydroxide was used as the framework, 1‑butyl‑3-methylimidazolium chloride ([Bmim]Cl) was selected as the N-dopped carbon source of the N-doped carbon coating, and ruthenium trichloride was chosen as the active metal precursor. The resultant catalyst was employed to catalyze the oxidation of 2000 ppm ammonia in an aqueous solution. N-doped carbon coating was placed on the zeolite surface, and the Ru nanoparticles on the catalyst were uniformly supported on the zeolite. Hence, the hydrothermal stability of zeolite was improved. The interaction between the Ru and N-doped carbon stabilizes the Ru species on the catalyst and improves the leaching resistance. The effect of different reaction conditions on the catalytic performance was investigated, and the stability of the catalyst was analyzed. 2 Experimental part 2.1 Material Ruthenium trichloride (RuCl3, 99%), sodium silicate (Na2SiO3, 99%), sodium aluminate (NaAlO2, 99%), ethanolamine (99%), ammonium hydroxide (25–28%), and sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 99%) were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). 2.2 Preparation of catalysts 2.2.1 Preparation of P-zeolite Typically, 0.28 g of NaOH, 5.55 g of sodium silicate, and 4 mL of ethanolamine were dissolved in 15 g of H2O at room temperature. 1.6 g of sodium aluminate was dissolved in 108 g of H2O. The above two solutions were mixed and aged at 50 °C for 4 h. The aged solution was put into an autoclave reactor and crystallized at 160 °C for 5 h. Then it was filtered, washed to neutral, and dried. Finally, P-zeolite was obtained by calcining the dried samples in a muffle furnace at 400 °C for 2 h. The calcined P-Zeolite was ground to powder form. 2.2.2 Preparation of alkali-treated P-zeolite The P-zeolite was added into NaOH solution (1 mol•L − 1) with a solid-liquid molar ratio of 1:9 and stirred at 50 °C for 6 h. Then it was filtered, flushed to neutral, and dried. The obtained sample was denoted as P-zeolite(NaOH). 2.2.3 Preparation of 1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH) Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH) was prepared by conventional impregnation with RuCl3 as the metal precursor. In a nutshell, P-zeolite(NaOH) (1 g) was added into 10 mL of water, and then 2.5 mL of RuCl3 solution (0.02 mol•L − 1) was added into the mixture. The sample was filtered, washed, and dried at 25 °C for 24 h. Then the sample was heated to 350 °C at a rate of 5 °C•min−1 in a tubular furnace and reduced by H2 for 2 h. The catalyst was obtained. The loading amount of Ru in 1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH), as determined by ICP, was 1.0 wt.%. 2.2.4 Preparation of 1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC Ionic liquid ([Bmim]Cl) was employed as a nitrogen doping carbon precursor. First, the 1-methylimidazole (8.21 g, 0.10 mol) and chlorobutane (11.11 g, 0.12 mol) were put into a 100 mL round-bottomed flask at room temperature and stirred for 20 min until the mixture was fully mixed. Under condensing reflux conditions, the mixture reacted at 45 °C for 2 h and then continued to react at 70 °C for another 24 h. Once the reaction was over, it was cooled down to room temperature and washed three times with ethyl acetate. A small amount of ethyl acetate was evaporated by rotary evaporator and [Bmim]Cl was obtained. Yield: 95%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO, TMS): δ (ppm) = 9.40 (s, 1H), 7.86 (s, 1H), 7.77 (s, 1H), 4.21 (t, 2H), 3.89 (s, 3H), 1.78 (m, 2H), 1.27 (m, 2H), 0.91 (t, 3H). Subsequently, 0.15 g of [Bmim]Cl and 2.5 mL of RuCl3 solution (0.02 mol•L − 1) were added into 15 g of ethanol. After ultrasonic dispersion for 5 min, 0.5 g of P-zeolite(NaOH) was added and ultrasonically dispersed for another 5 min. Then the mixture was stirred at 25 °C for 9 h. The mixed solution was transferred to a Petri dish, left to stand at 60 °C for 12 h. The sample was calcined in a tubular furnace under N2 flow at 500 °C for 2 h. The precursor was heated to 350 °C at a rate of 5 °C•min−1 in a tubular furnace and reduced with H2 for 2 h. Then the catalyst was obtained ( Scheme 1 ). The loading amount of Ru in 1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC, as determined by ICP, was 1.0 wt.%. 2.2.5 Preparation of 1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@C For comparison, a carbon-coated catalyst with glucose as a precursor was prepared using the same process, named as 1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@C. 2.3 Characterization The ruthenium content was determined by Agilent 5110 inductively coupled plasma emission spectrometry (ICP-OES). The specific surface area, total pore volume, and average pore size of samples were carried out with the Autosorb iQ nitrogen adsorption instrument. The crystal structure of the samples were tested by X-ray diffraction (XRD, D/MAX/2500 PC). The XRD data in the 2θ range from 10° to 80° were recorded at the scanning speed of 5°•min−1. The surface morphology of the sample was manipulated on the Hitachi S4800 scanning electron microscope (SEM). A transmission electron microscope (TEM, FEI Tecnai F30) was adopted to observe the pore structure of the sample and the size of the nanoparticles. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) characterization was performed on device ThermoFischer ESCALAB 250Xi using Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV) as the X-ray source. The working voltage and current is 12.5 kV and 16 mA, respectively. The C 1 s binding energy at 284.50 eV was utilized as the energy standard for calibration. The hydrothermal stability of samples was estimated by the temperature-programmed desorption of water vapor (H2O-TPD, AutoChem1 II 2920). The adsorption-desorption curve of water vapor was based on the signal at mass 18 (H2O). 2.4 Test of catalysts in CWAO of the highly concentrated ammonia The catalytic reaction was operated in a stainless steel reactor, equipped with a volume of 15 mL polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) to prevent the reactor inner wall corrosion. Usually, in each reaction, 50 mg of catalyst and 5 mL of 2000 ppm ammonia were added to the PTFE liner. Then oxygen was added to regulate the initial pressure of the reaction. Finally, the reaction kettle was heated to the required temperature, and the catalytic oxidation reaction was carried out at a magnetic stirring rate of 300 rpm. After the reaction, the reaction kettle was taken out of the heating mantle and quenched to room temperature in ice water. The liquid mixture and solid catalysts were collected separately. The concentrations of ammonia–nitrogen, NO2 −, and NO3 − in the liquid phase were analyzed. Among them, the concentration of ammonia–nitrogen was determined by Nessler's reagent spectrophotometry method, the concentration of total nitrogen was measured by alkaline potassium persulfate digestion UV spectrophotometric method, and then the selectivity to N2 was calculated. The ammonia conversion ( X N H 3 ) and nitrogen selectivity ( S N 2 ) were calculated as follows. (1) X N H 3 = C N H 3 0 − C N H 3 C N H 3 0 × 100 % (2) S N 2 = ( 1 − C N O 3 − + C N O 2 − C N H 3 0 − C N H 3 ) × 100 % where C N H 3 0 and C N H 3 indicate the initial and final concentration of ammonia–nitrogen in the solution, respectively; C N O 3 − and C N O 2 − indicate the NO3 − and NO2 − concentration after the reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of Ru/P-zeolite coated with N-doped carbon As seen in Scheme 1 , the catalyst of Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC was prepared through various processes, including hydrothermal synthesis, sodium hydroxide corrosion, simultaneous introduction of ionic liquid and Ru precursor, carbonization, and reduction. The hydrothermal synthesis of zeolite is the most commonly used method. The mixture prepared at a certain ratio becomes a white gel after stirring evenly, then placed in a hydrothermal reactor to crystallize at a set temperature. It is worth noting that local overheating should be avoided during calcination, or it will affect the product quality. The calcined P-zeolite was treated with sodium hydroxide solution to introduce surface defects and cracks [48], enhancing the absorption capacity of active metals. Meanwhile, alkali treatment can increase the mesoporous structure of the zeolite [45], which is conducive to mass transfer and heat transfer, thereby synergistically improving the catalytic performance. Due to ionic liquid has an excellent complexing effect with metal ions, simultaneous introduction of ionic liquid and Ru precursor is helpful to disperse Ru ions on the P-zeolite(NaOH). After calcination, it can form the N-doped carbon coating to anchor the Ru ions with good dispersion on the surface of the zeolite. The obtained Ru nanoparticles are not easy to aggregate into large clusters in the reduction process, which improves the utilization of the active metals. Besides, the presence of the N-doped carbon coating on the surface of zeolite can prevent the leaching of Ru nanoparticles in the CWAO of highly concentrated ammonia, and enhance the hydrophobic properties of P-zeolite(NaOH), thereby improving its hydrothermal stability. The prepared catalyst Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC overcame the poor hydrothermal stability of zeolite and exhibited excellent catalytic performance in the CWAO of highly concentrated ammonia. 3.2 Characterization of catalysts The specific surface area, total pore volume, and average pore size of the P-zeolite(NaOH) support and the catalysts are shown in Table 1 , and the catalysts exhibit a rich mesoporous structure. The specific surface area of Ru/P-zeolite@NC is 12.33 m2•g − 1, the average pore size is 3.81 nm, and the pore volume is 0.018 cm3•g − 1. It can be observed that the introduction of the precious metal Ru makes the specific surface area of the 1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC catalyst is slightly smaller than that of the support (P-zeolite(NaOH)), which may be ascribed to the N-doped carbon coating obstructing part of the pores. The above Fig. 1 shows the N2 adsorption and desorption isotherm and the BJH pore size distribution curves of the samples. As can be seen from Fig. 1 a, the curves of P-zeolite(NaOH) before and after loaded ruthenium are similar, belonging to type IV of IUPA classification. Moreover, when the relative pressure of the medium is about 0.3–0.8 (P/P0), the narrow H4 hysteresis loop of the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm appears, which is related to the pores generated by the layered structure. The pore size distribution diagram shows that most of the pores are distributed in the range of 2–10 nm, and the mean pore size is approximately 3.8 nm. The results indicate that the synthesized catalyst has an ordered and uniform mesoporous structure that facilitates mass transfer during the reaction. The XRD results of the P-zeolite and the catalyst are shown in Fig. 2 . The synthesized product has a certain intensity of diffraction peaks at the diffraction angles of 12°, 17°, 21°, 28°, and 33°, which are ascribed to P-zeolite [52]. In addition, the crystal morphology of the P-zeolite(NaOH) did not change after mild treatment with dilute alkali solution in the process of alkali treatment. That means the P-zeolite(NaOH) still retains the original framework of P-zeolite. The introduction of Ru and the nitrogen-doped coating do not cause a significant change in the XRD spectrum of the 1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC. No crystal phase composed of Ru or RuO2 is observed on the surface of the carrier. There may be two reasons. The first is Ru or RuO2 with a good dispersion was on the surface of the carrier [31, 53]. The second is that the ruthenium content is too low to show on XRD. For the resulting catalyst, when ruthenium content is 1.0 wt.%, it is more likely that the presence of highly dispersed nano-sized ruthenium particles on the support. SEM images of the zeolite and the zeolite samples after alkali treatment are shown in Fig. 3 . The parent zeolite exhibits a regular cubic crystal structure. Through the SEM images, it can be found that the particle size of the zeolite is approximately 2 μm and visible cracks and defects are present on the surface after alkali treatment. Besides, the surface of the zeolite becomes rougher, which may be caused by the dissolution of silica. The SEM image ( Fig. 3 c) shows that the catalyst exhibits regular cubic crystal. In order to verify the presence of N-doped carbon and Ru coating on the catalyst, an EDS mapping analysis is performed on 1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC. The elemental map of the catalyst shows that carbon (C), nitrogen (N) and ruthenium (Ru) are uniformly dispersed on the P-zeolite(NaOH) carrier. The spatial correlation between Al, C, and N elements indicates that N-doped carbon is in close contact with the P-zeolite carrier, which verifies the existence of N-doped carbon coating on the surface of the P-zeolite. Furthermore, the SEM elemental mapping image of ruthenium shows its uniform distribution on the support. This finding corresponds to the XPS results. Due to the strong interaction between metal and support, the active metal can be evenly dispersed on the carrier. The lattice plane, size, and distribution of ruthenium nanoparticles on the carrier are further explored by TEM. The TEM images of the P-zeolite(NaOH) supported ruthenium catalyst (1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)) prepared by the conventional impregnation method and the N-doped carbon-coated Ru/P-zeolite catalyst (1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC) are shown in Fig. 4 . In Fig. 4 a, although the average Ru nanoparticles are approximately 2.6 nm, the Ru particles have poor dispersibility and tend to aggregate into large particles. In contrast to Fig. 4 b, on the carrier coated with N-doped carbon, the Ru particles are evenly dispersed without accumulation, forming a uniformly dispersed Ru with a small particle size; the average metal particle size is approximately 1.5 nm. This phenomenon occurs because there is an electron transfer effect between Ru and N after the zeolite coating. N has an anchoring effect on Ru, making it uniformly dispersed on the carrier. The small particle size of ruthenium increases the number of metal atoms around the carrier interface and promotes its oxidation activity, in good agreement with the experimental results. Besides, as shown in Figs. 4 b and 4 e, the HRTEM image clearly shows the (101) plane of Ru with a lattice spacing of 0.21 nm [54]. The XPS curve fitting of P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC and 1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC samples are shown in Fig. 5 . It can be seen from Fig. 5 a that Ru0 shows two peaks at 276.20 eV and 280.37 eV, corresponding to the 3d2/3 and 3d2/5 level of Ru0, respectively. Ruδ+ shows two peaks at 277.07 eV and 281.24 eV, corresponding to Ruδ+ 3d2/3[55] and Ruδ+3d2/5, respectively [55]. Fig. 5 b shows the XPS curve fitting of Ru on the 3p orbital, which is consistent with the 3d orbital. In order to further determine the electronic transfer effect between the NC coating and the active metal Ru, we prepared an N-doped carbon coated P-zeolite(NaOH) sample without metal Ru, named P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC, and performed XPS analysis on it. The XPS curve fitting of N is shown in Fig. 5 c. It can be seen that after Ru is loaded, the binding energy of N 1 s moves from 400.21 to 399.07 eV, which is due to the presence of electron transfer from Ru to N, so Ruδ+ species is also observed [32]. The interaction between the N-doped carbon coating and the metal Ru disperses the active metal on the carrier stably and uniformly, which improves the leaching resistance of the catalyst and its activity in the ammonia–nitrogen wet catalytic oxidation reaction. 3.3 The catalyst performance evaluation Fig. 6 shows that for 2000 ppm ammonia water, the conversion rate and selectivity of 1%Ru/P-zeolite prepared by conventional impregnation method are 83.0% and 83.9%, respectively. After alkali treatment, the conversion rate is increased to 89.0%. This phenomenon may be caused by the fact that p-zeolite after alkali treatment shows a defect site that is beneficial to the adsorption of active metals, which improves its activity in the catalytic oxidation of high concentration ammonia. The conversion and selectivity of the catalyst (1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@C) coated with glucose generated carbon are slightly lower than those of 1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH). The catalysts coated with N-doped carbon has the best ammonia–nitrogen conversion and nitrogen selectivity. This phenomenon occurs because the simultaneous introduction of ionic liquids and Ru precursors facilitate the impregnation of metallic precursors. Owing to the electron transfer between N and the active metal, the N-doped carbon coating can effectively anchor and disperse the Ru nanoparticles. TEM images show that 1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC has a small metal particle size, which is beneficial to increase the number of metal atoms around the interface of the carrier and promote its oxidation activity. According to the ICP analysis results of the filtrate after the reaction ( Table 4 ), 1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC has high ammonia–nitrogen conversion activity and excellent hydrothermal stability. Compared with the cases reported in the literature in Table 2 , the catalytic activity of Ru/ P-Zeolite(NaOH)@NC catalyst prepared by us reached the advanced level, and the loading capacity of 1% was relatively low. For industrial applications, our catalysts are relatively stable and can be used multiple times. Even if Ru price rises now, also has certain industrial application value. The influence of different Ru loadings on the CWAO of the highly concentrated ammonia was studied, and the results are shown in Table 3 . At 200 °C, the catalyst conversion rate of 0.5% and 1% Ru loading could reach 100.0%. However, when 1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC was employed as a catalyst, the selectivity to N2 reached 85.4%, while using 0.5%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC, the selectivity was only 73.8%. The conversion rate of 2%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC was only 79.3%, which might be caused by the aggregation of active metals on the support. Hence, 1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC was chosen to study the effect of temperature, pressure, and other conditions on the CWAO of highly concentrated ammonia–nitrogen wastewater. The effect of the reaction temperature on the CWAO of the highly concentrated ammonia was further investigated. Table 4 shows that 1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC has an excellent effect on the CWAO of ammonia-nitrogen wastewater. Even at 180 °C, more than 85.0% of removal is achieved. When the temperature is increased from 180 °C to 210 °C, the conversion rate of the 1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC catalyst also increases from 87.0% to 100.0%. Although the increase in temperature improves the ammonia-nitrogen conversion activity, the selectivity of 1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC catalyst to N2 remains at a high level in the entire temperature test range. Therefore, N2 selectivity is less affected by temperature. Subsequently, the effect of reaction time on the CWAO is investigated. The result indicates that the conversion rate increases with the extension of the reaction time, and N2 selectivity does not change as the reaction time increases from 4 h to 5 h. The initial pH of the solution was 11 before the reaction. Under the reaction conditions of 200 °C, 4 h, and 2 MPa O2, the post-reaction solution was acidic, and its final pH was 6. As the carrier of catalytic wet oxidation ammonia, the thermal stability of zeolite will be affected by water and alkaline resistance. The cycle of our experiments also showed that coated catalyst used for which the cycling experiment, after three times circulation, conversion rate has fallen to sixty percent. XRD patterns also showed the loss of crystal structure. We use N-doped carbon coating coated alkali-treated zeolite as the carrier of catalytic wet oxidation of ammonia, which overcomes the shortcomings of poor hydrothermal stability and poor alkaline resistance of zeolite and has good stability in such a reaction system. Table 4 also compares ammonia conversion of 1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC catalyst under 1.5 MPa and 2.0 MPa at 190 °C and 200 °C, respectively. The results showed that when the pressure of oxygen is increased from 1.5 MPa to 2.0 MPa, the conversion rate of ammonia-nitrogen do not change significantly. According to the following reaction, the pressure only slightly affects the conversion rate of ammonia–nitrogen: (3) 4 N H 3 + 3 O 2 = 2 N 2 + 6 H 2 O According to the specific size of the reactor, the requirement of O2 for a certain amount of ammonia reaction (5 mL, 2000 ppm) is approximately 0.07 MPa. Therefore, the pressure of O2> 1.5 MPa has a slight effect on the reaction. At the end of the reaction, the content of ammonia nitrogen and total nitrogen in the reaction solution were measured. Nitrate nitrogen was equal to the total nitrogen minus the ammonia nitrogen. The amount of NO2 – and NO3 – in the solution was determined by ion chromatography. It was consistent with what we were calculated. No NO2 – was found in the solution after the reaction. Therefore, we speculate that the reaction mechanism of catalytic wet oxidation of ammonia on Ru/P-Zeolite (NaOH)@NC is as reported by LEE et al. (4) O 2 ( aq ) + 2 * ↔ 2 O * (5) N H 3 ( aq ) + O * → NH * + H 2 O (6) NH * + O * ↔ NHO * + * (7) NHO * + O * ↔ HN O 2 + 2 * (8) HN O 2 ↔ H + + N O 2 − (9) N O 2 − + N H 4 + → N 2 + 2 H 2 O (10) N O 2 − + O * → N O 3 − + * 3.4 The hydrothermal stability of the catalysts To evaluate the hydrothermal stability of the catalyst, we carried out TPD of water vapor experiments, analyzed the filtrate using ICP after the reaction, compared the XRD patterns before and after the catalyst cycle, and examined the reusability of the catalysts through cycling experiments. The TPD profiles of water adsorption on 1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH) and 1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC ( Fig. 7 ) show that the N-doped carbon-coated catalyst adsorbs less water than the uncoated catalyst. Since the measured surface areas of the two samples are approximately equal, the area of the TPD profile indicates the amount of water adsorbed on the sample surface. The introduction of a thin carbon layer increases the hydrophobicity of the carrier and reduces the amount of water adsorption on the N-doped carbon coating sample. The enhanced hydrophobicity of the carrier endows its resistance to hydrolyze at high temperatures and improves hydrothermal stability. Hence, 1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC catalyst has better hydrothermal resistance than the common zeolite. This finding is consistent with the leaching results of the active metal loaded on different carriers after repeated use tested by ICP ( Table 5 ). After the reaction, the collected filtrate was used to measure the leaching amount of the active metal Ru obtained by ICP ( Table 5 ). The catalyst with N-doped carbon coating after NaOH treatment has the lowest leaching rate of active metal at only 0.03%. Compared with that of the uncoated (18.10%) and without alkali-treated (8.75%) samples, the leaching resistance of the metal was greatly improved. In addition, the presence of N-doped carbon coating enhances the hydrophobicity of P-zeolite, as confirmed by TPD. With the increase in hydrophobicity, the P-zeolite can resist the invasion of high-temperature hydrolysis under hydrothermal conditions and improve the leaching resistance of active metals. The N-doped carbon coating effectively anchors Ru nanoparticles through the electron transfer effect between N and Ru, allowing the Ru nanoparticles to exist stably on the P-zeolite. When completing the reaction, the catalyst was collected, filtered, washed, dried, and reduced for the next reaction. The results of the cycle test are shown in Fig. 8 . For Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH) catalyst, the conversion rate remarkably dropped from 89% to 63.5% after three-cycle reactions. However, Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC catalyst showed excellent recyclability. After five cycles, the ammonia–nitrogen conversion rate and N2 selectivity of the catalyst have remained at high levels, and the conversion rates are above 95%. This result may be that the interaction between the Ru and N-doped carbon stabilizes the Ru species on the catalyst. Moreover, the high-temperature sintering of the active metal during reduction might be the reason for the slight decrease in catalyst activity. Fig. 9 a shows that the XRD pattern of the catalyst does not change significantly after the reaction. After five cycles, the characteristic peak of P-zeolite is still the main XRD pattern of the used catalyst. As shown in Fig. 9 b, the XRD pattern of the catalyst has changed significantly after the reaction, and the characteristic peak becomes inconspicuous. Therefore, the designed Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC catalyst has better hydrothermal stability than the commonly used zeolite catalyst. 4 Conclusion The prepared 1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC catalyst was used to wet catalytic oxidation of highly concentrated ammonia–nitrogen wastewater. The catalyst with a low loading capacity has a good effect on the CWAO of highly concentrated ammonia–nitrogen wastewater under relatively mild conditions. The alkali treatment increases the surface defect sites of the carrier, and the NC coating increased the hydrothermal stability of the catalyst. Owing to the interaction between N and metal, the active metal is uniformly and stably dispersed on the P-zeolite carrier, thus improving the stability of the catalyst in the CWAO. 5 Synopsis This study provides an effective strategy for the application of N-doped carbon coating on zeolite in the CWAO of high-concentration ammonia nitrogen wastewater. coredata.dc:description: The treatment of the highly concentrated ammonia–nitrogen wastewater major produced in the coal chemical industry is a challenging problem. Herein, a novel catalyst with high activity and hydrothermal stability was designed for the catalytic wet air oxidation (CWAO) of the highly concentrated ammonia. In the designed catalytic system, P-zeolite was treated with sodium hydroxide to form defects for enhancing the adsorption of active metals. And the ionic liquid was employed as an N-doped carbon coating on treated P-zeolite to protect the ruthenium nanoparticles from leaching and improve its hydrothermal stability. The simultaneous introduction of ionic liquid and Ru precursor was beneficial to the dispersion of Ru on P-zeolite. The resulting catalyst Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC overcomes the poor hydrothermal stability of zeolite and exhibits excellent catalytic performance during the CWAO of highly concentrated ammonia. The catalyst of 1%Ru/P-zeolite(NaOH)@NC offers 100% conversion under 2 MPa at 200 °C in 4 h for 2000 ppm ammonia. No substantial deactivation was observed after five cycles. This study provides an effective strategy for the application of N-doped carbon coating on zeolite in CWAO systems.
coredata.dc:title: Nitrogen doping carbon deriving from ionic liquid anchoring Ru coated on P-zeolite as high activity and stability catalyst for the catalytic wet air oxidation of highly concentrated ammonia
